segment.source: BCDBoot Command-Line Options
segment.target: BCDBoot Command-Line Options

segment.source: BCDBoot Command-Line Options
segment.target: BCDBoot Command-Line Options

segment.source: BCDBoot Command-Line Options
segment.target: BCDBoot Command-Line Options

segment.source: BCDBoot is a command-line tool used to configure the boot files on a PC or device to run the Windows operating system.
segment.target: BCDBoot is a command-line tool used to configure the boot files on a PC or device to run the Windows operating system.

segment.source: You can use the tool in the following scenarios:
segment.target: You can use the tool in the following scenarios:

segment.source: Add boot files to a PC after applying a new Windows image.
segment.target: Add boot files to a PC after applying a new Windows image.

segment.source: In a typical image-based Windows deployment, use BCDBoot to set up the firmware and system partition to boot to your image.
segment.target: In a typical image-based Windows deployment, use BCDBoot to set up the firmware and system partition to boot to your image.

segment.source: To learn more, see Capture and Apply Windows, System, and Recovery Partitions.
segment.target: To learn more, see Capture and Apply Windows, System, and Recovery Partitions.

segment.source: Set up the PC to boot to a virtual hard disk (VHD) file that includes a Windows image.
segment.target: Set up the PC to boot to a virtual hard disk (VHD) file that includes a Windows image.

segment.source: To learn more, see Boot to VHD (Native Boot): Add a Virtual Hard Disk to the Boot Menu.
segment.target: To learn more, see Boot to VHD (Native Boot): Add a Virtual Hard Disk to the Boot Menu.

segment.source: Repair the system partition.
segment.target: Repair the system partition.

segment.source: If the system partition has been corrupted, you can use BCDBoot to recreate the system partition files by using new copies of these files from the Windows partition.
segment.target: If the system partition has been corrupted, you can use BCDBoot to recreate the system partition files by using new copies of these files from the Windows partition.

segment.source: Set up or repair the boot menu on a dual-boot PC.
segment.target: Set up or repair the boot menu on a dual-boot PC.

segment.source: If you've installed more than one copy of Windows on a PC, you can use BCDBoot to add or repair the boot menu.
segment.target: If you've installed more than one copy of Windows on a PC, you can use BCDBoot to add or repair the boot menu.

segment.source: File Locations
segment.target: File Locations

segment.source: In Windows and Windows Preinstallation Environment (WinPE)
segment.target: In Windows and Windows Preinstallation Environment (WinPE)

segment.source: %WINDIR%\System32\BCDBoot.exe
segment.target: %WINDIR%\System32\BCDBoot.exe

segment.source: In the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK):
segment.target: In the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK):

segment.source: C:\Program Files (x86)\Windows Kits\10\Assessment and Deployment Kit\Deployment Tools\amd64\BCDBoot\BCDBoot.exe
segment.target: C:\Program Files (x86)\Windows Kits\10\Assessment and Deployment Kit\Deployment Tools\amd64\BCDBoot\BCDBoot.exe

segment.source: Supported operating systems
segment.target: Supported operating systems

segment.source: BCDBoot can copy boot environment files from images of Windows 10, Windows 8.1, Windows 8, Windows 7, Windows Vista, Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview, Windows Server 2012 R2, Windows Server 2012, Windows Server 2008 R2, or Windows Server 2008.
segment.target: BCDBoot can copy boot environment files from images of Windows 10, Windows 8.1, Windows 8, Windows 7, Windows Vista, Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview, Windows Server 2012 R2, Windows Server 2012, Windows Server 2008 R2, or Windows Server 2008.

segment.source: How It Works
segment.target: How It Works

segment.source: To configure the system partition, BCDBoot copies a small set of boot-environment files from the installed Windows image to the system partition.
segment.target: To configure the system partition, BCDBoot copies a small set of boot-environment files from the installed Windows image to the system partition.

segment.source: BCDBoot can create a Boot Configuration Data (BCD) store on the system partition using the latest version of the Windows files:
segment.target: BCDBoot can create a Boot Configuration Data (BCD) store on the system partition using the latest version of the Windows files:

segment.source: BCDBoot creates a new BCD store and initialize the BCD boot-environment files on the system partition, including the Windows Boot Manager, using the %WINDIR%System32ConfigBCD-Template file.
segment.target: BCDBoot creates a new BCD store and initialize the BCD boot-environment files on the system partition, including the Windows Boot Manager, using the %WINDIR%System32ConfigBCD-Template file.

segment.source: New in Windows 10: During an upgrade, BCDBoot preserves any other existing boot entries, such as debugsettings, when creating the new store.
segment.target: New in Windows 10: During an upgrade, BCDBoot preserves any other existing boot entries, such as debugsettings, when creating the new store.

segment.source: Use the /c option to ignore the old settings and start fresh with a new BCD store.
segment.target: Use the /c option to ignore the old settings and start fresh with a new BCD store.

segment.source: If there is already a boot entry for this Windows partition, by default, BCDBoot erases the old boot entry and its values.
segment.target: If there is already a boot entry for this Windows partition, by default, BCDBoot erases the old boot entry and its values.

segment.source: Use the /m option to retain the values from an existing boot entry when you update the system files.
segment.target: Use the /m option to retain the values from an existing boot entry when you update the system files.

segment.source: By default, BCDBoot moves the boot entry for the selected Windows partition to the top of the Windows Boot Manager boot order.
segment.target: By default, BCDBoot moves the boot entry for the selected Windows partition to the top of the Windows Boot Manager boot order.

segment.source: Use the /d option to preserve the existing boot order.
segment.target: Use the /d option to preserve the existing boot order.

segment.source: On UEFI PCs, BCDBoot can update the firmware entries in the device’s NVRAM:
segment.target: On UEFI PCs, BCDBoot can update the firmware entries in the device’s NVRAM:

segment.source: BCDBoot adds a firmware entry in the NVRAM to point to the Windows Boot Manager.
segment.target: BCDBoot adds a firmware entry in the NVRAM to point to the Windows Boot Manager.

segment.source: By default, this entry is placed as the first item in the boot list.
segment.target: By default, this entry is placed as the first item in the boot list.

segment.source: Use the /p option to preserve the existing UEFI boot order.
segment.target: Use the /p option to preserve the existing UEFI boot order.

segment.source: Use /addlast to add it to the bottom of the boot order list.
segment.target: Use /addlast to add it to the bottom of the boot order list.

segment.source: Command-Line Options
segment.target: Command-Line Options

segment.source: The following command-line options are available for BCDBoot.exe.
segment.target: The following command-line options are available for BCDBoot.exe.

segment.source:
BCDBOOT
source
/l
locale
/s
volume-letter
/f
firmware type
/v
/m {OS Loader GUID}/addlast or /p/d/c
segment.target:
BCDBOOT
source
/l
locale
/s
volume-letter
/f
firmware type
/v
/m {OS Loader GUID}/addlast or /p/d/c

segment.source: Option
segment.target: Option

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: source
segment.target: source

segment.source: Required.
segment.target: Required.

segment.source: Specifies the location of the Windows directory to use as the source for copying boot-environment files.
segment.target: Specifies the location of the Windows directory to use as the source for copying boot-environment files.

segment.source: The following example initializes the system partition by using BCD files from the C:\Windows folder:
segment.target: The following example initializes the system partition by using BCD files from the C:\Windows folder:

segment.source: /l locale
segment.target: /l locale

segment.source: Optional.
segment.target: Optional.

segment.source: Specifies the locale.
segment.target: Specifies the locale.

segment.source: The default is US English ().
segment.target: The default is US English ().

segment.source: The following example sets the default BCD locale to Japanese:
segment.target: The following example sets the default BCD locale to Japanese:

segment.source: /s volume letter
segment.target: /s volume letter

segment.source: Optional.
segment.target: Optional.

segment.source: Specifies the volume letter of the system partition.
segment.target: Specifies the volume letter of the system partition.

segment.source: This option should not be used in typical deployment scenarios.
segment.target: This option should not be used in typical deployment scenarios.

segment.source: Use this setting to specify a system partition when you are configuring a drive that will be booted on another computer, such as a USB flash drive or a secondary hard drive.
segment.target: Use this setting to specify a system partition when you are configuring a drive that will be booted on another computer, such as a USB flash drive or a secondary hard drive.

segment.source: UEFI:
segment.target: UEFI:

segment.source: BCDBoot copies the boot files to either the EFI system partition, or the partition specified by the /s option.
segment.target: BCDBoot copies the boot files to either the EFI system partition, or the partition specified by the /s option.

segment.source: BCDBoot creates the BCD store in the same partition.
segment.target: BCDBoot creates the BCD store in the same partition.

segment.source: By default, BCDBoot creates a Windows Boot Manager entry in the NVRAM on the firmware to identify the boot files on the system partition.
segment.target: By default, BCDBoot creates a Windows Boot Manager entry in the NVRAM on the firmware to identify the boot files on the system partition.

segment.source: If the /s option is used, then this entry is not created.
segment.target: If the /s option is used, then this entry is not created.

segment.source: Instead, BCDBoot relies on the default firmware settings to identify the boot files on the system partition.
segment.target: Instead, BCDBoot relies on the default firmware settings to identify the boot files on the system partition.

segment.source: By the UEFI 2.3.1 spec, the default firmware settings should open the file: \efi\boot\bootx64.efi in the EFI System Partition (ESP).
segment.target: By the UEFI 2.3.1 spec, the default firmware settings should open the file: \efi\boot\bootx64.efi in the EFI System Partition (ESP).

segment.source: BIOS:
segment.target: BIOS:

segment.source: BCDBoot copies the boot files to either the active partition on the primary hard drive, or the partition specified by the /s option.
segment.target: BCDBoot copies the boot files to either the active partition on the primary hard drive, or the partition specified by the /s option.

segment.source: BCDBoot creates the BCD store in the same partition.
segment.target: BCDBoot creates the BCD store in the same partition.

segment.source: The following example copies BCD files from the C:\Windows folder to a system partition on a secondary hard drive that will be booted on another computer.
segment.target: The following example copies BCD files from the C:\Windows folder to a system partition on a secondary hard drive that will be booted on another computer.

segment.source: The system partition on the secondary drive was assigned the volume letter S:
segment.target: The system partition on the secondary drive was assigned the volume letter S:

segment.source: The following example creates boot entries on a USB flash drive with the volume letter F, including boot files to support either a UEFI-based or a BIOS-based computer:
segment.target: The following example creates boot entries on a USB flash drive with the volume letter F, including boot files to support either a UEFI-based or a BIOS-based computer:

segment.source: /f firmware type
segment.target: /f firmware type

segment.source: Optional.
segment.target: Optional.

segment.source: Specifies the firmware type.
segment.target: Specifies the firmware type.

segment.source: Valid values include , , and .
segment.target: Valid values include , , and .

segment.source: On BIOS/MBR-based systems, the default value is .
segment.target: On BIOS/MBR-based systems, the default value is .

segment.source: This option creates the \Boot directory on the system partition and copies all required boot-environment files to this directory.
segment.target: This option creates the \Boot directory on the system partition and copies all required boot-environment files to this directory.

segment.source: On UEFI/GPT-based systems, the default value is .
segment.target: On UEFI/GPT-based systems, the default value is .

segment.source: This option creates the \Efi\Microsoft\Boot directory and copies all required boot-environment files to this directory.
segment.target: This option creates the \Efi\Microsoft\Boot directory and copies all required boot-environment files to this directory.

segment.source: When you specify the value, BCDBoot creates both the \Boot and the \Efi\Microsoft\Boot directories, and copies all required boot-environment files for BIOS and UEFI to these directories.
segment.target: When you specify the value, BCDBoot creates both the \Boot and the \Efi\Microsoft\Boot directories, and copies all required boot-environment files for BIOS and UEFI to these directories.

segment.source: If you specify the /f option, you must also specify the /s option to identify the volume letter of the system partition.
segment.target: If you specify the /f option, you must also specify the /s option to identify the volume letter of the system partition.

segment.source: The following example copies BCD files that support booting on either a UEFI-based or a BIOS-based computer from the C:\Windows folder to a USB flash drive that was assigned the volume letter F:
segment.target: The following example copies BCD files that support booting on either a UEFI-based or a BIOS-based computer from the C:\Windows folder to a USB flash drive that was assigned the volume letter F:

segment.source: /v
segment.target: /v

segment.source: Optional.
segment.target: Optional.

segment.source: Enables verbose mode.
segment.target: Enables verbose mode.

segment.source: Example:
segment.target: Example:

segment.source: /m [{OS Loader GUID}]
segment.target: /m [{OS Loader GUID}]

segment.source: Optional.
segment.target: Optional.

segment.source: Merges the values from an existing boot entry into a new boot entry.
segment.target: Merges the values from an existing boot entry into a new boot entry.

segment.source: By default, this option merges only global objects.
segment.target: By default, this option merges only global objects.

segment.source: If you specify an OS Loader GUID, this option merges the loader object in the system template to produce a bootable entry.
segment.target: If you specify an OS Loader GUID, this option merges the loader object in the system template to produce a bootable entry.

segment.source: The following example merges the operating-system loader in the current BCD store that the specified GUID identifies in the new BCD store:
segment.target: The following example merges the operating-system loader in the current BCD store that the specified GUID identifies in the new BCD store:

segment.source: /addlast
segment.target: /addlast

segment.source: Optional.
segment.target: Optional.

segment.source: Specifies that the Windows Boot Manager firmware entry should be added last.
segment.target: Specifies that the Windows Boot Manager firmware entry should be added last.

segment.source: The default behavior is to add it first.
segment.target: The default behavior is to add it first.

segment.source: Cannot be used with /p.
segment.target: Cannot be used with /p.

segment.source: /p
segment.target: /p

segment.source: Optional.
segment.target: Optional.

segment.source: Specifies that the existing Windows Boot Manager firmware entry position should be preserved in the UEFI boot order.
segment.target: Specifies that the existing Windows Boot Manager firmware entry position should be preserved in the UEFI boot order.

segment.source: If entry does not exist, a new entry is added in the first position.
segment.target: If entry does not exist, a new entry is added in the first position.

segment.source: Cannot be used with /addlast.
segment.target: Cannot be used with /addlast.

segment.source: By default, during an upgrade BCDBoot moves the Windows Boot Manager to be the first entry in the UEFI boot order.
segment.target: By default, during an upgrade BCDBoot moves the Windows Boot Manager to be the first entry in the UEFI boot order.

segment.source: /d
segment.target: /d

segment.source: Optional.
segment.target: Optional.

segment.source: Preserves the existing default operating system entry in the {bootmgr} object in Windows Boot Manager.
segment.target: Preserves the existing default operating system entry in the {bootmgr} object in Windows Boot Manager.

segment.source: /c
segment.target: /c

segment.source: Optional.
segment.target: Optional.

segment.source: Specifies that any existing BCD elements should not be migrated.
segment.target: Specifies that any existing BCD elements should not be migrated.

segment.source: New for Windows 10: By default, during an upgrade, BCD elements such as debugsettings or flightsigning are preserved.
segment.target: New for Windows 10: By default, during an upgrade, BCD elements such as debugsettings or flightsigning are preserved.

segment.source: Repair the system partition
segment.target: Repair the system partition

segment.source: If the system partition has been corrupted, you can use BCDBoot to recreate the system partition files by using new copies of these files from the Windows partition.
segment.target: If the system partition has been corrupted, you can use BCDBoot to recreate the system partition files by using new copies of these files from the Windows partition.

segment.source: Boot your PC to a command line.
segment.target: Boot your PC to a command line.

segment.source: For example, boot to the Windows installation disk and press Shift+F10, or boot to Windows PE (WinPE: Create USB Bootable drive).
segment.target: For example, boot to the Windows installation disk and press Shift+F10, or boot to Windows PE (WinPE: Create USB Bootable drive).

segment.source: Use Diskpart to determine which drive letter contains your Windows partition and system partition ().
segment.target: Use Diskpart to determine which drive letter contains your Windows partition and system partition ().

segment.source: Optional: Format your system partition:
segment.target: Optional: Format your system partition:

segment.source: Add a boot entry for your Windows partition:
segment.target: Add a boot entry for your Windows partition:

segment.source: Reboot the PC.
segment.target: Reboot the PC.

segment.source: Windows should appear.
segment.target: Windows should appear.

segment.source: Set up or repair the boot menu on a dual-boot PC
segment.target: Set up or repair the boot menu on a dual-boot PC

segment.source: When setting up a PC to boot more than one operating system, you may sometimes lose the ability to boot into one of the operating systems.
segment.target: When setting up a PC to boot more than one operating system, you may sometimes lose the ability to boot into one of the operating systems.

segment.source: The BCDBoot option allows you to quickly add boot options for a Windows-based operating system.
segment.target: The BCDBoot option allows you to quickly add boot options for a Windows-based operating system.

segment.source: To set up a dual-boot PC:
segment.target: To set up a dual-boot PC:

segment.source: Install a separate hard drive or prepare a separate partition for each operating system.
segment.target: Install a separate hard drive or prepare a separate partition for each operating system.

segment.source: Install the operating systems.
segment.target: Install the operating systems.

segment.source: For example, if your PC has Windows 7, install Windows 10 onto the other hard drive or partition.
segment.target: For example, if your PC has Windows 7, install Windows 10 onto the other hard drive or partition.

segment.source: Reboot the PC.
segment.target: Reboot the PC.

segment.source: The boot menus should appear with both operating systems listed.
segment.target: The boot menus should appear with both operating systems listed.

segment.source: If both operating systems aren't listed:
segment.target: If both operating systems aren't listed:

segment.source: Open a command line, either as an administrator from inside Windows, or by booting to a command line using the Windows installation media and pressing Shift+F10, or by booting to Windows PE (WinPE: Create USB Bootable drive).
segment.target: Open a command line, either as an administrator from inside Windows, or by booting to a command line using the Windows installation media and pressing Shift+F10, or by booting to Windows PE (WinPE: Create USB Bootable drive).

segment.source: Add boot options for a Windows operating system.
segment.target: Add boot options for a Windows operating system.

segment.source: Reboot the PC.
segment.target: Reboot the PC.

segment.source: Now, the boot menu will show both menu options.
segment.target: Now, the boot menu will show both menu options.

segment.source: Troubleshooting
segment.target: Troubleshooting

segment.source: For information about repairing the boot files on a PC with Windows XP and a more recent version of Windows such as Windows 7, see the Microsoft Knowledge Base Article 2277998.
segment.target: For information about repairing the boot files on a PC with Windows XP and a more recent version of Windows such as Windows 7, see the Microsoft Knowledge Base Article 2277998.
